history.content:
Here are a few posts that I've starred that you might find interesting.

@4475 Answers by Prof. Anant Sahai and EMS god Sinho Chewi.

@8510 Some more in-depth answers on the math side of things.

children.subject:
I can testify to the usefulness of Stat 134, Math 110, 104, 202A and 128A to grad level ML/AI classes; a lot of concepts from these math classes show up in my courses such as EE229A (information theory), EE222 (nonlinear systems), Stat 210A (mathematical/theoretical statistics), and even CS 270 (the optimization and measure concentration material)

I think double majoring in EMS sounds like a great way to prepare for research work in AI, ML, statistical signal processing, control etc and I know some graduate students who did this; for me though, I sometimes regret doubling in Math and not taking more CS major classes related to ML instead because certain math classes I had to take such as 113 were just not very relevant. Also, Math 185 isn't completely irrelevant but is at most tangentially related to ML.

history.content:
I'm a sophomore tryna get a stronger technical foundation in ML/AI/Grad-stuff so I'm looking at the EMS major for courses to take that are the most application-based to supplement my EECS/Software curriculum 

Mandatory courses are Math 110, 104, 105 or 185, 128A, and Stat 134

In terms of the variable courses I can choose from, rn I'm looking at math 105, 170, 113, 118, or stat 135. What math courses are the most ml-applicable? Also if anyone else did some eecs/ems combo what was their experience like/general advice pls?
history.subject: Doubling in EECS and Engineering Math and Stats
